Leave, Sisters, leave your hellish work,</br>(Cry'd Helda loud from Sussex cliffs)</br>No longer after Mischief lurk;—</br>At Hastings, see her plumes she lifts:</br>While darts and purpl'd jav'lins clear the way,</br>See — grim she sits, and smiles on Harold's natal day.

Haste, Sisters, haste, leave — leave your charms!</br>Haste — Haste — and join the Norman Song;</br>(Hark — boldly sung 'midst clash of arms)</br>Such bloody strains to you belong:—</br>'Twas Mischief's self inspir'd the deaf'ning lay,</br>And Hell its music lent — for Harold's natal day.

Seek, Sisters, now no bestial blood,</br>Haste, Haste, where human curses flow;</br>Like o'erwill'd Severn's roaring flood,</br>Gushing they spread — and roar with woe;</br>And 'midst their streams the meeting lances play,</br>And well-pleas'd Mischief laughs at Harold's natal day.

Seek, Sisters, now no nook obscene,</br>To hide from day your dark wove spells;</br>Here, not a ray of light is seen,</br>An arrowy cloud thro' aether swells.</br>Delighted Mischief guides the hurtling way,</br>And throws a blasting night o'er Harold's natal day.

Seek, Sisters, now no lion's heart,</br>Its gen'rous blood o'er charms to pour,—</br>Loud-woful whizz'd yon Norman dart—</br>And Harold pants in Harold's gore!</br>And see — the English fly — the Normans sway—</br>While Death and Mischief laugh at Harold's natal day.

Hark, Sisters, hark — while I foretell—</br>Joy to us thro' William's reign:</br>Joy to ev'ry tribe of Hell,—</br>For Harold's loss is Mischief's gain.</br>Towns sink for woods, and man to beast gives way!</br>Haste, and with Mischief laugh at Harold's natal day.</br>
